history.provenance: Herculaneum, Insula IV.21, House of the StagsErcolano (Napoli), Insula IV.21, Casa dei Cervi

div.p:
Textus et mensurae secundum (1)
v. 1: II scriptum pro littera E
De hoc cognomine, vide EDR126746 quo ONESIMVS in Tabula Herculanense ter apparet.
Onesimus

Transliterated Greek name Ονησιμος, meaning useful. This name appears six times in Herculaneum (five times as Onesimus and once as (O)νηcιμοc), 17 times in Pompeii (sixteen times as Onesimus and once as Honesimus), once in Surrentum (Onesimus), once in Neapolis (Onesi[mus]), and twelve times in Puteoli (all Onesimus). Many of them are freed slaves, though the name seems popular as a Romen cognomen as well. Cf. 10598.

CIL 04, 10561 (1)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR151866 (2)
Graffito naming Onesimus

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Insula IV.8, House of the Painted PapyrusErcolano (Napoli), Insula IV.8, Casa del Papiro Dipinto

div.p:
Textus et mensurae secundum (1); periit (2).
Contulerunt sed non invenerunt Clikeman, Damer, Jepsen, MacDonald (HGP) a. 2016.
v. 1: II scriptum pro littera E
Myrine to the sea (?)

Myrine is a transliterated name from the Greek Μυρρινε. In the process of transliteration the name is simplified by having a rho drop out from the Greek. Μυρρινε is a popular Greek name and was the name of a character in Aristophanes' play Lysistrata. The name appears elsewhere in Italy - 7 times total, including twice in Pompeii.

CIL 04, 10521 (1)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR151829 (2)
Graffito naming Myrine

history.provenance: Herculaneum, null.0, Not foundErcolano (Napoli), Insula IV.6, Facade

div.p:
Textus et mensurae secundum (2); periit (3).
Contulerunt et non invenerunt Brewer, Benefiel, Helms, Sypniewsk (HGP) a. 2016.
v. 1-2: Saturnina[e] / matr(i) uncus (detur?) (1)
v. 3: omisit (1)
Mensurae:
v. 1: lat.: 23,6; litt. alt.: 2,9-6,7
v. 2: lat.: 19,6; litt. alt.: 1,7-4,5
v. 3: lat.: 9,2; litt. alt.: 2,5-5,0
For Saturnina, a mother, a hook that costs three asses (coins).
Women's names were often repeated in a family, so, both sisters in the Domitius family could be named Domitia, or, as here, perhaps the mother and daughter might share the same name, Saturnina.

Rend. Ac. Arch. Nap., 33, 1958, p. 265, nr. 307 (M. Della Corte) (1)
CIL 04, 10519 (2)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR140171 (3)
Graffito mentioning a price

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Insula III.19, House of the InnErcolano (Napoli), Insula III.19, Casa dell'Albergo

div.p:
Textus secundum (1)
Prope EDR154588
4 Publius Quin(tilius?)

This graffito could either be in reference to a name or to a date. If it was a name the P would stand for Publius and the Quin for Quintilius. Quin can also be a n abbreviation for the month Quintilis, which was the orginial fifth month of the calendar year until it got renamed Iulius for Julius Caesar. If the Quin did stand for Quintilis, the graffito would be a date and the P could be a mistaken reading of a K which would stand for kalends. Then the meaning of this graffito would be four days before the kalends of Quintilis.

CIL 04, 10512 (1)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR140204 (2)
Graffito

div.ab: XVII kalendas, X kalendas, VII idus

div.p: Textus et mensurae secundum (1), contulit et non invenit Loar (HGP) a. 2014
17 days before the Kalends, 10 days before the Kalends, 7 days before the Ides
This is an example of a graffito with dates, many graffiti had this format. For more on the dating system used in the Roman Empire look to the commentary in CIL IV.10579.

V Kalendas
Germanus

div.p:
Textus secundum (1).
v. 3: alt. 1,2 cm.
Primus et Felix et fortasse et Germanus nominantur etiam in EDR168161.
Seven days before the Kalends, Primus. Six days before the Kalends, Felix. Five days before the Kalends, Germanicus

CIL 04, 04044 (1).
J. Frost DiBiasie, The Writings on the Wall: the Spatial and Literary Context of Domestic Graffiti from Pompeii, Diss The University of Texas Austin 2015, p. 217 and p. 221 (2)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR168160 (3)
Appointment calendar

Done in wet plaster with large letters in the female baths, possibly by one of the workers plastering the walls, this graffito is still very visible today.

Prope EDR142442
(... other letters here...) Cossutius(?)
Cossutius is a nomen gentilicium. However, Cossutius may not be related to Ceres. It is written far enough below it to make it's inclusion in the same entry dubious.

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Outside Walls.ow1, RampErcolano (Napoli), Rampa

div.ab:
Longinus IV Idus Iulias
IuliasIualias accepit vim hilare
Sturnus amator

div.p:
Textus secundum (1); mensurae secundum (2)
Periit (4)
Contulerunt sed non invenerunt Dillard, King, et Loar (HGP) a. 2016.
v. 1: lat.: 9,5; litt. alt.: 3,0-5,0
v. 2: lat.: 10,4; litt. alt.: 0,2-1,8
v. 3: lat.: 6,0; litt. alt.: 0,3-1,0
vv. 1-2: quod prius in tectorio fracto esset, IVLIAS scriptum bis (2)
v. 2: aut HILA(RIS) (2)
v. 3: [- - -]S TVRNVS (3) quod STVRNVS ut nomen non attestatur, sed incertum est utrum tectorium mutilum esset.
Prope EDR140979, EDR154429, EDR154430, EDR154431, EDR154432, EDR154433, EDR140980, EDR140982, EDR140983, EDR140986, EDR154537
Longinus - Four days before the Ides of July, he received physical force cheerfully. Starling(?)...

there are two date tags on the tag list; it is possible that this writer wrote IULIAS for the month of July twice; RRB: I don't see Sturnus ever used as a name; it's a starling. Turnus doesn't appear as a name either. S(a)turnus maybe, suggests RRB?

Rend. Ac. Arch. Nap., 33, 1958, p. 302, nr. 806 (M. Della Corte) (1)
CIL 04, 10694 (2)
Gnomon 45, 1973, p. 272 (H. Solin) (3)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR154434 (4)
Erotic graffito

v. 1: II scripta pro littera E
Supra EDR151800, EDR151801, et EDR151802.

Mus could be a name or the animal mouse, the meaning is unclear here. The name Mus appears elsewhere in Herculaneum, CIL IV.10678 and CIL IV.10643c. If Mus is a name, it would be an insult becuase the graffito would be translated as useless Mus. 4 graffiti appeared together. One says mus nequam. Three others are false starts on mus nequa.

CIL 04, 10498a (1)

Graffito

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Insula IV.21, House of the StagsErcolano (Napoli), Insula IV.21, Casa dei Cervi

div.p:
Textus secundum (3), mensurae secundum (2). Contulit et emendavit R. Benefiel a. 2018 ex apographo.
v. 1: C. Ostius (1)(2), sed Ostius pro nomine Hostius scriptum erat.
Contulerunt et non invenerunt Clikeman, Damer, Jepsen, MacDonald (HGP) a. 2016. Tectorium collapsum est.
Caius Ostius

This graffito could be the name Hostius. The letter H is often dropped off the beginning of words because it is pronounced more softly, therefore an inscriber having only heard the name might not know that an H starts the name. The name Costius, or Ostius (making the inscription C(aius) Ostius, do not exist, so Hostius would be the closest name.

Rend. Ac. Arch. Nap., 33, 1958, p. 268, n. 350 (M. Della Corte) (1)
CIL 04, 10558 (2)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR151863 (3)

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Outside Walls.ow1, RampErcolano (Napoli), Rampa

div.p:
Textus et mensurae secundum (1). Contulerunt prehenderunt Dillard, King, Loar, Benefiel (HGP) a. 2016.
Status litterarum a. 2016.
v. 1: titulus lapide rubro scriptus est secundum (1), sed videtur pictus esse (2). Praeter R, litteris valde abrasis.
Prope EDR154539, EDR154540, EDR140987, EDR154541, EDR156779, EDR154542
Good luck, Proculus.
The CIL says this graffito is written in red rock. Part of this graffito does appear to be scratched, but some of it (namely the R in ROCULO) appears to be painted.

CIL 04, 10700 (1)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR154538 (2)
Greetings to Proculus

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Insula VI.1,7-10, Central BathsErcolano (Napoli), Insula VI.1,7-10, Terme Centrali

div.p:
Textus et mensurae secundum (1); periit (2).
Contulerunt sed non invenerunt Gibson, Hardy, Minnear, Smith (HGP) a. 2016.
v. 1: prima autem littera potest esse etiam D, ut primum verbum conici possit [OVI]DIO (1).
v. 1: lat.: 34,7; litt. alt.: 1,1-13,8
v. 2: lat.: 25,1; litt. alt.: 3,1-5,0
(... other letters here...) you will die in Tomis. Good luck!
Tomis was an ancient city in Dacia, on the western side of the Black Sea. It is well known because it is where Ovid was sent for his exile.

CIL 04, 10595 (1)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR151890 (2)
Graffito mentioning the city Tomis

div.p: There may be a partly-visible diagonal letter trace before alpha in line 1, in which case it is tempting to suppose that we have the name Πυριλάμπης, whether beginning in this line or above. There is ample room to the left, but we do not see any traces remaining.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 159-160.
Uncertain

history.provenance: Herculaneum, null.0, Not foundErcolano (Napoli), Insula V.35, Casa del Gran Portale, Facade

div.p:
Textus secundum (1). Contulerunt et mensuras Beall, Bey IV, McCrory, Opdenhoff, Zimmermann Damer (HGP) a. 2014.
v. 1: Tantum vestigia litterae B primae remanent a. 2016; tectortium valde abrasum est. In ultima B erat titulus EDR140057.
HGP mensurae, alt.: 26,1
HGP mensurae, lat.: 18,6
HGP mensurae, litt. alt.: 14-23,8
Balbus

This graffito may be referring to Marcus Nonius Balbus, who was a patron of Herculaneum. He was the benefactor of many public buildings, such as the basilica. After his death the town erected a statue and plaque which listed his honors and deeds for the city, this inscription can be found as EDR073648. The l and the b are in nexus.

CIL 04, 10588a (1)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR140127 (2)
Beginning of a name

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Insula Orientalis II.2-3Ercolano (Napoli), Insula Orientalis II.2-3, Pistrinum

div.p:
Textus et mensura secundum (2)
v. 1: [C]IINEDE (1) vel C̣INEDE (2) pro CINAEDE
v. 1: II pro littera E scriptum
Contulerunt et mensurae prehenderunt Lundqvist, Dollings, Thayer, Crawford, et Toscano (HGP) a. 2014
HGP mensurae, alt.: 13,0
HGP mensurae, lat.: 27,5
HGP mensurae, litt. alt.: 2,8-13,0
Prope EDR154570, EDR154571, EDR154572, EDR140251, EDR140252
Pervert!

Cinaedus referes specifically to the passive reciever of a sexual encounter. It can also be used loosly to refer to an effeminate man. Here, the author of the graffito has placed cinaede in the vocative case, or, rather, the provacitive case, as he calls anyone who walks by cinaedus.

Rend. Ac. Arch. Nap., 33, 1958, p. 281, nr. 547 (1)
CIL 04, 10654d (2)
A. Varone, Titulorum graphio exaratorum qui in CIL vol. IV collecti sunt Imagines, Roma 2012, vol. II, p. 504, con foto (3)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR154573 (4)

div.ab:
Augustalis Pierus Celadus
Papiri servum Amandumum
medicavit

div.p:
Textus et mensurae secundum (2).
v. 1: Aug(ustalis?) scriptum ut AUC; Celadus vel Claudus (2).
Scriptum non graphio sed penicillo colore albo (calce) ductum (2), iscrizione tracciata con grosso pennello e con latte di calce direttamente sul nudo 'incertum' della parete. Il latte di calce, dove più dove meno, aveva ancora presa sulle nude pietre e sulla malta di contorno (1).

Not. Sc., 64, 1939, p. 304, nr. 399 (M. Della Corte) (1)
CIL 04, 08810 (2)
Hackworth Petersen, L. 2006, The Freedman in Roman Art and Art History, p. 251, n. 36 (3)

HGP mensurae, lat.: 71,0
HGP mensurae, litt. Alt.: 3,5 (I in MIAM)-17,0 (S in SIRA)
Prope EDR153740, EDR153741, EDR153800, EDR154423
(unknown meaning)

Written in large letters in the wet plaster above the lavatory, the meaning of this graffito is uncertain. Charca and sira have no known meaning in the Latin language. Della Corte suggests Calca meam (mentulam?), Syra, where Syra is someone's name.

CIL 04, 10648 (1)
Gnomon, 45, 1973, p. 276 (H. Solin) (2)
A. Varone, Titulorum graphio, exaratorum qui in CIL vol. IV collecti sunt Imagines, Roma 2012, vol. II, p. 502, con foto (3)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR140211 (4)
Graffito

Prope EDR152931
Cake (or loaf of bread). (symbol). MME.

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Insula IV.15-16, Grand TabernaErcolano (Napoli), Insula IV.15-16, Grande Taberna

div.p:
Textus secundum (1), lapsu tectorii periit (2).
Prope EDR140220, EDR140224, EDR140230, EDR140231, EDR140213
Of Vibidius (?) OR Vibidi(us...?)

Vibidius is a nomen gentilicium and appears througout the Italian peninsula. It also appears twice in the catalogue of names at Herculaneum CIL X.01403. There is appears as the nomen gentilicium of two freedmen, who would have taken that name from their master. Both of the Vibidius' mentioned are freedmen of Aulus Vibidius which we can tell becasue both names say freedmen of Aulus, and becuase it is customary for a freedmen to take the praenomen of his master. This shows that the Vibidius fmaily in Herculaneum owned slaves and was wealthy.

CIL 04, 10537 (1)
A. Varone, Titulorum graphio exaratorum qui in CIL vol. IV collecti sunt, Imagines, Roma 2012, vol. II, p. 488, con foto (2)

history.provenance: Herculaneum, null.0, Not foundErcolano (Napoli), Insula III.16-17, Facade

div.p:
Textus secundum (2-3), aliter (1).
Contulerunt et mensuras prehenderunt Clikeman, Damer, Jepsen, MacDonald (HGP) a. 2016.
v. 1: ALCIMUS legitur apud (1)
Prope EDR140143
We are cold.

There are different interpretations of this graffito. In CIL the reading is Alcimus which would be a male name. However when Varone went through Herculaneum he read this as the verb algemus from algeo algere. After looking at the inscription on site, we agreed with Varone's reading.

CIL 04, 10508b (1)
Riv. Stud. Pomp., 11, 2000, 278, fig. 1a, con apografo (A. Varone) (2)
A. Varone, Titulorum graphio exaratorum qui in CIL vol. IV collecti sunt, Imagines, Roma 2012, vol. II, p. 485, con foto (3)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR140149 (4)

div.p:
Textus secundum (2), mensurae secundum (3).
Contulerunt et mensuras prehenderunt Gibson, Hardy, Minnear, Smith (HGP) a. 2016.
v. 1-3: status litterarum a. 2016 (3).
vv.1-3: Exstabat omnis titulus a. 1994 (2), sed dextra pars tectorii fracta erat a. 2017 (3).

Mensurae pro integri titulo secundum (1):
v. 1: lat. 9,1; litt. alt. 2,3-3,2
v. 2: lat. 14,5; litt. alt. 1,4-2,0
v. 3: lat. 7,2; litt. alt. 1,9-2,8
Prope EDR152963, EDR152964, EDR152999, EDR154590, EDR154591
Kalends of August, Nones of April at Atina.

Textus secundum (1) (3), contulerunt et mensuras prehenderunt Hicks, Rebman, Rasmussen, Nyhuis, Helms (HGP) a. 2014.
v. 1: RVFVLA PVS, Cipriotti apud (2), qui potius Σ ad Hor. S. 1.7.1 de usu PVS confert; litterae VL in nexu (3).
Mensurae (HGP) a. 2014:
alt.: 14,0
lat.: 24,5
litt. alt.: 2,5-14,0
Rufula, 5 1/2 pounds

Many different possibilities exist for these final three letters. Della Corte first suggested ... pondo v semis... Or perhaps only part of the word was written and the writer meant to inscribe pusilla (very small or petty), pusulata (blistered, refined) or pusillanimis (timid, faint-hearted- but late authors)

decoDesc.decoNote: FELICITER written in the shape of a boat

history.provenance: Herculaneum, Insula Orientalis I.2, House of the Telephus ReliefErcolano (Napoli), Insula Orientalis I.2, Casa del Rilievo di Telefo

div.p:
Textus secundum (2)
v. 1: FELITER pro FELICITER; II scriptum pro E.
v. 1: littera T pro malo carinae scripta est.
Contulerunt at mensuras prehenderunt Brewer, Handloser, Helms, Maddy, Nyhuis (HGP) a. 2016.
HGP mensurae totius tituli (litterarum imaginisque):
HGP mensurae, alt.: 29,9
HGP mensurae, lat.: 66,0
HGP mensurae litterarum solum:
HGP mensurae, litt. alt.: 1,4 (ultima E)-27,0 (T)
Prope EDR140834 et EDR140835
Good luck!

Inscribed within a ship with the T as the mast and the letters as ours, this graffito marks a prominent place on one of the walls in the House of the Telephus Relief. Today it is badly faded and nearly illegible. In any case, the inscriber spelled it feliter, eliminating a full sylable. Examples of nautical technopaegnion (writting names in the form of ships) like this occur throughout Herculaneum and Pompeii. For other examples, see CIL IV.10655a.,CIL IV.10655b., and CIL IV.10652.

Rend. Ac. Arch. Nap., 33, 1958, p. 275, nr. 439 (M. Della Corte) (1)
CIL 04, 10622 (2)
A. Varone, Titulorum graphio exaratorum qui in CIL vol. IV collecti sunt Imagines, Roma 2012, vol. II, p. 501, con foto (3)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR140054 (4)

v. 2: lat.: 5,5; litt. alt.: 2,0-2,5
v. 1: SANN(A)E (1), (3)
vv. 1-2: in columno porticus septentrionalis secundo ab oriente
v. 2: fortasse ad Poppaea Sabina refert (2), sed sine ratione

Contulerunt et mensuras prehenderunt Brewer, Helms, Maddy, Jepsen, Nyhuis (HGP) a. 2016.
vv. 1-2: HGP mensurae, alt.: 6,7
vv. 1-2: HGP mensurae, lat.: 11,5
vv. 1-2: HGP mensurae, litt. alt. 2,0-4,5
Prope EDR156982
Sabina, Sabina

The name Sabina is written twice on this column, which stands on the north side of the Decumanus Maximus, the main road of town. Sabin(a) is first written in cursive lettering. Below, it is then written in capital letters. (Cf. Varone 2000: 279.)

An. Pont. Inst. Sup., 13, 1963, p. 288, nr. 197 (V. Catalano) (1)
Riv. Stud. Pomp., 11, 2000, p. 279, fig. 1c, con apografo (A. Varone) (2)
V. Catalano, Gli abitanti e culti di Ercolano, a cura di L. Garcia y Garcia e G. Panzera, Roma 2002, p. 111 con foto, Tav. XXXIX 1 (3)
Graffito naming Sabina

Prope EDR154538, EDR154539, EDR154540, EDR154541, EDR156779, EDR154542
Marcus

div.p:
Textus et mensurae secundum (2); periit (3).
Contulit et non invenit Benefiel et DiBiasie-Sammons (HGP) a. 2016.
v. 1: PISV (1) sed RISV ex apographo collato (2).
v. 2: Lectiones consideratae apud (2): [TOR]QVATUS, aut QVATVS scriptum pro QVATTVS vel QVARTVS vel QVATTVOR vel QVADRVPLVM. II pro littera E scriptum.
v. 1: lat.: 5,3; litt. alt.: 0,4-1,2
v. 2: lat.: 6,5; litt. alt.: 0,4-0,8
v. 3: lat.: 4,6; litt. alt.: 0,4-1,8
Prope et eadem manu ut EDR154567 et EDR154569
There exist (...other letters here...) ...fourth(?) not five

Della Corte suggests risu for pisu (laughter verses pea-plant) and reads the missing portion of quatus as the name (Tor)quatus, though he also suggests quartus (quarter) and quattuor (four) and quadruplum (quadruple). See CIL IV.1679 Add. p. 463 for quadtus as quattor. CIL IV.10632a., b., and c. may be the only graffiti with written numbers, perhaps indicating that this was a single, one time transaction, one not subject to change, essentially set in stone (or in this case, plaster).

Rend. Ac. Arch. Nap., 33, 1958, p. 278, nr. 476 (M. Della Corte) (1)
CIL 04, 10632b (2)
http://ancientgraffiti.org/Graffiti/graffito/AGP-EDR154568 (3)
Numerical graffito

div.p: “Two gold coins [aurei]” is followed by additional letters, presumably giving the start of the word ending in ματα, which is then followed by the conjunction καί and another word, of which there are probably additional traces now barely visible.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 355-356.
Reference to Coins

div.p: 2. LGPN 2.375 records an archaic instance of a name Πολύπους on a black-figured vase, as Thomas Corsten points out to us. Whether this name, apparently not attested elsewhere (no other examples in LGPN online search), is to be read here, we do not know.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 363-364.
Good wishes

div.ab:
Α
ΕΝΗ
ΣΑΠΑΤΡΟΣ
ΕΠΕΘΗΗ
Ι ΤΩ
Ι ΡΑ

div.p: 1. ατα is possible; the letter before alpha has a hasta placed well to the left of alpha. 2. The letter before epsilon does not seem to be gamma. 3. One should perhaps divide –σα πατρός. 4. The penultimate letter appears to have two hastas, as eta or nu, but we have not found a convincing reading. There is more than ordinary space between pi and epsilon, but no traces. 5–6. The vertical lines indicate where the text crosses the bevel edge.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 151-152.
Uncertain

bibl.publisher: First published by the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World and the New York University Press, 2016.

provenance.placeName: Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey

div.p:
1. Scanty as the traces are, they suggest the possibility of reading [φιλῶ] ἧς ὁ [ἀρι|θμὸς] ψν
. There may be a trace before psi in line 2, but this is not certain. If this interpretation is correct, it indicates a love object whose name was valued isopsephistically at 750 or at a number in the range 751–759. There are at least seven feminine names in LGPN 5A in this range. Cf. Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 48.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 157.
Love Declaration?

Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 245.

div.p: “(Being healed in) my eyes by the gods, I give thanks to the Baite.”
See Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 42 and 44, for healings of eyes and for Baite.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 264; Bagnall, R., Everyday Writing in the Graeco-Roman East (2011): 22 and 21, fig. 9; SEG 61.969.

div.p: There is no sign of any following letters that would allow this to be seen as the beginning of a word or name, such as a Greek rendering of Quintus or Quietus. It could be intended for Κῷε, the vocative of “Coan”. We have no other explanation to offer.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 293.
Uncertain

div.ab:
φιλῶ ἧς ὁ ἀριθμὸς
χις οπολλ

div.p: “I love a woman whose number is 616.”

1. See Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 48. 2. There is no name or other element following the formula in the other instances of this formula, and, given the break at right, it is not obvious what the letters visible here are intended to mean.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 226.
Declaration of Love

div.p: 1. Cf. T29.1, ἐκράφη σου, with apparently kappa for gamma. This fragmentary graffito may reflect the same idiom, but too much is lost to say more.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 227.
Uncertain

provenance.placeName: Basilica of the Agora of Smyrna, Izmir, Turkey

div.ab:
ΚΟΤΗ
ΤΟΟΥΔΙΝ
Ἀσίας τύχη
ΩΣ
ΦΥΛΑΞΕΥΟΖΥ
ΓΟΚΑΜΕΜΕ
τόποςτώπος

div.p: 3. Not much is visible of the second sigma of Ἀσίας, but it seems syntactically unavoidable. 4. A horizontal trench has been cut in the plaster to eliminate whatever was originally written here. 5–6. φυλάξε = φυλάξαι? Perhaps following that we should read ὑπ̣οζυ|γόκαμε̣ν̣ (l. ὑπεζυγώκαμεν), requiring two phonetic errors to get an acceptable perfect form of the unattested compound ὑποζυγόω (the simplex is known).
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 424-426.
Uncertain

div.ab:
ζήτημα
Εἴσιδι αδι
αδι διασω
θείς αδι α
δι’ Ἰσίδωρος
ΕΝ

div.p: “Riddle: To Isis (adi adi), having been saved (adi adi), Isidoros . . .”
1. On riddles, see Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 54. 2. Read Ἴσιδι.
Bagnall, R. S. et al., Graffiti from the Basilica in the Agora of Smyrna (2016): 271; Bagnall, R. S., Everyday Writing in the Graeco-Roman East (2011): 19; SEG 61.964.
Riddle
